title: Cathie Wood Drops MASSIVE Prediction

You know people are comparing it to cash flows. One of those numbers are wrong. It's just the cash flow is wrong. We are addressing the largest software opportunity in history. Everything from the way they social media works and the way they they recommend ads and help uh advertisers create content has fundamentally been changed and their earnings show it and that's the reason why they're investing so hard. They see just a much larger future potential for it and not just one company. This is going to affect AWS is shopping and the way they recommend goods. But it costs something up front. As an investor I'll just tell you this. I want my personal net worth I want my funds net worth levered against AI because all human progress is going to be derived from machines helping humans think and augment human thinking. So whether it's owning Nvidia, which is our largest public position, or whether it's Anthropic or OpenAI, all of these companies are going to be tremendous beneficiaries, and they're doing it at scale. There are increasing advantages to scale, right? And so I think it's hard for people to get their arms around now, just like it was in 2008 and 2009. But thank god Jeff Bezos did that. Now it's $140 billion business generating 30 billion a year in annual profits that people criticized him for investing in back then. How can I just It's incredible that OpenAI and Anthropic are 20 billion run rate companies pro generating profitable revenues and accelerating growth all at the same time. These are extraordinary things and it makes perfect sense from where we sit. Isn't it inevitable that we're going to at some point overdo it, but we're not going to know that until it's too late? >> It's not like roads. Roads once you lay it down, it stays fairly useful for a long time. The way computers work is you build up the infrastructure, but then you start replacing it five, six, seven years later. And so I think it's going to take us some seven years, eight years to build up to the level that we have to sustain. And after that, we're going to be refreshing and slightly growing. And so we've got several years of build out ahead of us. >> Every major AI company is hitting the same wall. They can't buy compute fast enough. And that constraint is what Jensen claims proves the market is real. Before we jump in, if you're trying to understand the AI infrastructure side of things, the chip, the compute, and why it all matters, I made a course called the AI landscape. This course is designed to break AI down in a digestible way. Links in the description. You get lifetime access, and the price goes up as we add new modules. And he says they're so computed that if they had twice as much infrastructure, their revenues would go up by up to four times. So, in his mind, this is a demand problem, not a supply problem. And he uses Meta as his proof. He says, "Nobody uses AI better than meta." They went from a basic recommendation system on CPUs to a generative AI system. Uh but I don't think it's going to be for a long time. So, really cut in half since its peak in October. What is going on here? Isn't Bitcoin supposed to be digital gold? If it's digital gold, why isn't it behaving like gold? Uh, and a a couple of points to make here. If you do the correlation between Bitcoin and gold, their returns uh since 2019 and and I put this in uh my New Year's letter. You can see the matrix there if you'd like. Um the correlation has been 0.14. Uh one is perfect correlation. Uh and here we are at 0.14 very low almost no correlation. Uh so that is very important to understand. AI capex has hit.com levels as a percentage of GDP and Kathy Wood argues today's earnings and multiples make this a completely different situation. So Kathy borrows this line from Brad Gersonner. The GPUs are not dark. In the com era, companies laid fiber optic cable everywhere and then nobody used it. The GPU version of that would be data centers full of chips with no workloads. Every GPU that shows up gets used immediately and the companies want more. Kathy does say though as an economist whenever she hears the word shortage she starts looking for a glut. She thinks one is coming eventually in chips just not for a while. Tech capex as a percentage of GDP is back at bubble levels and that makes people nervous especially the fund managers who were young during the 2000s who are now the gray hairs running these organizations. Their instinct is protect the portfolio. We've seen this movie before. Kathy gets that, but her counter is the technology timeline. Back in the '9s, the vision was years ahead of what was possible. People didn't get cloud until 2006. Deep learning was 2012. Transformers came in 2017 and chat GBT that actually made AI useful to normal people was in late 2022. So, we've had like 3ish years of real usable AI. Her point is we're still super early. Then she gets to valuations, and this is probably the strongest part of what she's saying. Gold moves on central bank buying, geopolitical stuff, currency fields. So, comparing them side by side is kind of misleading. They're doing different things for different people. Very profitable businesses. So in the case of take Salesforce, it's gone from 30 times free cash flow multiple to 15 times. That means somebody buying it today says listen, I think 15 years into the future, I can count on these free cash flows. Right? Before they were willing to pay 30 years into the future. summary_hu: A videóban Cathie Wood és más elemzők a mesterséges intelligencia (AI) növekvő gazdasági hatását és az iparági környezetet elemzik. Wood szerint a szoftverfejlesztés sohasem volt ilyen jelentős, és a vállalatok kamatoztatják az AI-ban rejlő lehetőségeket, ami indokolttá teszi a magas capital expenditure-t, amely elérheti a 660 milliárd dollárt. A Meta példáján bemutatja, hogy az AI ujraértelmezi a keresletet és a felhasználói tapasztalatokat, különösen a hirdetések terén. Az AI infrastruktúra fejlődése lassú, de tartós növekedést jövendöl. A Bitcoin piacán ellentmondások mutatkoznak, mivel az ára csökkent, teljesítménye nem tükrözi a sárga fémval fenntartott kapcsolatát. Általánosan a videó pozitív kilátásokat mutat a technológiai szektor, különösen az AI területén.
summary_en: The video analyzes the economic impact of artificial intelligence (AI) through insights from Cathie Wood and other experts. Wood argues that software development has never been more significant, and companies are capitalizing on AI opportunities, justifying high capital expenditures that could reach $660 billion. Using Meta as an example, she illustrates how AI redefines demand and user experiences, particularly in advertising. The development of AI infrastructure is slow but predicts sustained growth ahead. There are discrepancies in the Bitcoin market, as its price has dropped contrary to its expected correlation with gold. Overall, the video presents a positive outlook for the technology sector, especially in the AI domain.
key_points_hu: A mesterséges intelligencia hatása a vállalati nyereségességre egyértelműen látható.
A Bitcoin ára jelentősen csökkent, miközben a hozzá fűzött elvárások ellentmondásosak.
A piaci szereplők, akik a dot-com buborék alatt tapasztaltak, most óvatosabbak a tőkebefektetések terén.
key_points_en: The impact of artificial intelligence on corporate profitability is clearly evident.
Bitcoin's price has significantly dropped, while expectations tied to it are contradictory.
Market players who experienced the dot-com bubble are now more cautious regarding capital investments.
main_topics: Investment in AI and technology infrastructure
Bitcoin's market performance compared to gold
